report_title: Internet Radio Broadcasting in the US
executive_summary: The Internet Radio Broadcasting industry's main revenue comes from online advertising from existing over-the-air radio stations and recommendation-based streaming platforms like Pandora. The industry doesn't include on-demand services like Spotify that let users select their music. Over the past five years, these platforms have become major competitors and have siphoned money and listeners away from the industry. The pandemic exacerbated this as consumers spent their money elsewhere while trapped indoors. With more people staying home, funds were redirected towards essential goods, streaming services and more interactive forms of home entertainment, causing a dip in advertising revenues for internet radio platforms reliant on commercial sponsors.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Growing Popularity of Mobile Devices and Smart Speakers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The rise in smartphone usage and the proliferation of smart speakers, like Amazon Echo and Google Home, have significantly impacted the Internet Radio Broadcasting industry. These devices provide convenient ways for listeners to access internet radio stations, driving more traffic to these platforms.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: INCREASED COMPETITION FROM MUSIC STREAMING SERVICES
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The rapid growth of on-demand music streaming services like Spotify, Apple Music and Amazon Music has caused significant strife in the industry. These platforms offer extensive libraries of on-demand music, curated playlists and personalized recommendations, addressing various user preferences.

Internet radio stations are increasingly offering exclusive content to attract and retain listeners. This includes exclusive interviews, live sessions, artist takeovers and special event coverage unavailable on standard streaming platforms.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Shifts in Advertising Models and Monetization Strategies
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: How listeners engage with internet radio has led to shifts in advertising models and monetization strategies. Traditional ad models, which relied heavily on high-volume ad insertions, are being supplemented or replaced by more targeted, personalized advertising solutions.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The industry is becoming more saturated as it ages and because of shifting consumer preferences, the presence of substitutes will continue to threaten internet radio broadcasting. Larger companies will aim to acquire more niche platforms to grow their audience and expand their products to slow the loss of demand to other streaming industries.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Mobile Content Growth Promises Opportunities and Challenges
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The continued market penetration of smartphones, tablets and other mobile devices will lead to the Internet Radio Broadcasting industry growth. Service prices will increase slowly because of rising operational costs, but the industry will stay relevant as consumers turn to digital platforms for convenience and diverse content offerings.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Digital Advertising Provides a Ray of Hope for Broadcasters
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the next five years, digital advertising will provide a bright spot for the industry amid several negative trends and encroachment from other industries. The industry's digital advertising segment will grow as more business is conducted online. As online business grows, more digital advertisements will reach a larger number of consumers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Subscription Models Will Drive Industry Shift
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Subscription services will increasingly offer advanced features and benefits to attract and retain users. An ad-free experience remains a primary draw, catering to listeners who prefer uninterrupted streaming.

industry_definition: Industry operators provide online streaming media distribution, including music and other audio programming. This industry only includes operators that control music recommendation and noninteractive internet radio platforms and generate revenue through subscription and advertising. This industry does not include subscription-based, on-demand online music streaming services.

threats: External competition for the Radio Broadcasting industry

key_trends: Top management strategizes for long-term sustainability amid rising competition from streaming giants. Prioritizing exclusive content, user experience and technological advancements will be critical to remaining relevant and profitable in this evolving market.

Free internet radio has become a significant industry substitute, offering consumers diverse music options without fees. This model challenges traditional broadcasters, forcing them to innovate and adapt to maintain their audience and revenue streams.

Broadcasters are challenged by music streaming services like Spotify and Apple Music, which have significantly diminished the demand for internet radio over the past five years. This shift has caused a notable decline in traditional radio listenership and ad revenue.
Smartphone and smart speaker adoption boosts the available audience. Devices like Amazon Echo and Google Home offer seamless access to internet radio but also benefit competing industries.

Niche internet radio broadcasters provide specialized content tailored to specific interests and communities. These platforms offer unique genres, themes and discussions, catering to audiences often overlooked by mainstream media.
Pandora has been on the rise. Strategic initiatives and expansion into new markets have boosted performance, positioning the brand for sustained success in a competitive landscape.

With more mobile phones having internet connections, consumers can easily access internet radio broadcasting, leading to increased subscriptions. This accessibility allows users to stream their favorite

market_segmentation.segment: Consumers Aged 45 to 64 Years of Age
market_segmentation.segment_description: Individuals in this age bracket typically have more discretionary income than younger age groups. They are often at the peak of their careers or starting to prepare for retirement, allowing for both financial stability and disposable income to spend on subscriptions and premium services. Many in this age group have grown up with traditional radio and have naturally transitioned to internet radio as technology has evolved. They often have more leisure time, especially as their children become independent and they approach retirement.

The second largest market comprises consumers aged 25 to 44. This group is digitally savvy and highly engaged with technology, making them prime candidates for internet radio services. They use internet radio for entertainment and as a source of news, education and background music during work or exercise.
The third largest market for internet radio broadcasting is consumers aged 24 and younger. This group has grown up with access to the internet and a wide array of digital content.
This demographic typically has lower engagement with internet radio because of several factors.

products_and_services.product_description: The largest service offering in the Internet Radio Broadcasting industry is online terrestrial radio station advertising. Terrestrial stations' dominance stems from the deep-rooted affiliation they have cultivated over decades in traditional broadcasting.
Online-only station advertising is the second largest service, driven by its ability to attract niche markets and specialized audiences.
Subscriptions are driven by the increasing consumer preference for premium, ad-free listening experiences.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: The number of mobile internet connections
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The number of mobile internet connections measures the number of internet-capable devices, such as smartphones and tablets.

business_locations.location_description: The region contains diverse demographics, high population density and significant economic growth.
Chicago, Detroit and Cleveland have long been media powerhouses that offer established infrastructure and a skilled workforce.
The West ranks third for internet radio broadcasters because of its innovative culture and technological leadership.
Major media region with diverse population.
Culturally rich region with historical media significance.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Broadcasters are expected to pay licensing fees to use copyrighted materials.
Industries must choose between interactive and non-interactive operation types because of differing regulations.

regulations_points.regulation_title: LISTENER PROTECTION AND DATA PRIVACY REGULATIONS
regulations_points.regulation_description: Regulations ensure that listener data is not misused.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Internet radio providers must obtain a statutory license from organizations like SoundExchange to broadcast copyrighted music.
Starting a cable network is costly because of licensing, employment, airtime and online services.

basis_points.basis_description: Because of high competition in internet radio, new companies and shows targeting local regions might achieve greater success.
Running these operations requires more capital than labor.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The Internet Radio Broadcasting industry prides itself on extensive offerings catering to a wide range of listener preferences.
Entering the Internet Radio Broadcasting industry presents several moderate barriers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: These employees command high salaries, driving up wage costs for broadcasters.
Purchases as a share of revenue have increased over the past five years.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Running these operations requires more capital than labor.
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Running these operations requires more capital than labor.

volatility_points.volatility_description: The number of listeners tuning in to internet radio stations can vary considerably based on the time of day.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Mobile devices have provided broadcasters with new platforms for on-the-go music listening.

FAQs.question: How reliant is your company on advertising revenue?
FAQs.answer: The majority of industry revenue is generated through the sale of advertisements.

FAQs.question: Does technology change for you customers significantly affect you company?
FAQs.answer: Companies must adapt to changing technology preferences.

FAQs.question: How do your depreciation and R&D spending levels compare with your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Depreciation expenses may come as a surprise for some companies.
